title: Documentary Filmmaker Susana de Sousa Dias on Revealing the Terror of Portugalâ€™s Fascist Regime
description: Portuguese documentary filmmaker Susana de Sousa Dias, who is the guest of honor at IDFA, spoke to the festivalâ€™s artistic director Isabel Arrate Fe
body:
Portuguese documentary filmmaker Susana de Sousa Dias, who is the guest of honor at IDFA, spoke to the festivalâ€™s artistic director Isabel Arrate Fernandez this week about how she set out to interrogate the repressive methods of her countryâ€™s fascist regime through an examination of its archives and footage from the period.

	De Sousa Dias, who was inspired to become a filmmaker by the masters of Italian neorealism such as Luchino Visconti, first became interested in re-examining historical subjects by delving into archives when she was asked to direct an episode of a series on Portuguese cinema.
	

	Her episode was on the period 1930 to 1945, during which fascism tightened its grip on Portugal, the start of a four-decade long reign of terror, presided over by AntÃ³nio de Oliveira Salazar.


	Following that, she came across the case of two Portuguese nurses who were jailed for protesting against a law barring nurses from getting married. She decided to make her first film, 2000â€™s â€œCriminal Case 141/53,â€ about the nurses, one of whom endured frequent beatings and solitary confinement.

	This led her to dive deeper into the archives left behind by the fascist regime, and specifically into the records of the political police, an archive that she says is extensive.

	This, in turn, led to her feature â€œStill Life,â€ released in 2005, which is based on news reports, propaganda films and images from prison archives, and â€œ48â€ in 2009, which juxtaposes the regimeâ€™s photographs of political prisoners with testimonies decades later, revealing the violence they were subjected to.
	

	She commented that it was her discovery of albums of photographs of imprisoned political prisoners that drove her to make â€œStill Life.â€ â€œIt made a huge impression on me, which I could not verbalize,â€ she said. But she was also conscious that there was so much that was missing â€“ the cruel stories behind the photographs. That is what she sought to uncover.

	â€œIf you go to the political police archive, you donâ€™t see any reference to torture. You see the reports on the interrogations of the prisoners, but they donâ€™t tell you that, meanwhile, they tortured them,â€ she said. â€œMy films, in a certain way, are trying to fill some of these gaps.â€

	She added that the police archives turned her view of the world upside down. â€œIt changed completely my perspective on life, my perspective on history, everything. Itâ€™s a very disturbing experience being inside the [police and military] archives,â€ she said.

	Nonetheless, she decided to only use images from the police and military archives and archive footage produced under the control of the dictatorship.

	This posed a dilemma for the director in that these photographs and footage were shot from the perspective of the dictatorship. â€œI wanted to show the other side of the dictatorship, and this obliged me to undertake deep research into the interior of the images,â€ she said.

	All of this was done in the editing, which she did herself on a Moviola, focusing on certain areas of the image and omitting others. She found herself looking for â€œsomething in the image that had escaped the message that the regime wanted to convey,â€ she said. These details in the images are what she calls â€œa montage within the shots.â€ She referred to an image as an â€œactive entityâ€ to be examined for meaning, asking, â€œWhat does an image do? And what does an image do to us?â€

	The filmâ€™s sound effects and music, which was composed by her brother, AntÃ³nio de Sousa Dias, helped her compose the images, and both the composition of the music and the editing process progressed hand-in-hand.

	â€œWhen I started editing, I didnâ€™t even know where I could start from,â€ she said. â€œBut when I heard this music, click, the whole film appeared in my mind. It was the concept: Iâ€™m going to organize the film like it is an exhibition, with different rooms.â€ These would include â€œthe rooms for the colonies, the rooms of war, the rooms of the church,â€ and so on.
	

	As time passed, the Portuguese authorities in charge of the archives made it more difficult for De Sousa Dias to access them by insisting on authorization being given by those in the photos through a process she called â€œKafkaesque.â€ But still she found ways to do so, she explained, without giving away her methods, although she quoted Werner Herzog, who said filmmakers need â€œgood criminal energyâ€ to make films.

	However, when she contacted the former inmates, she found they could also give her the backstory to their prison mugshots. That led to another realization. â€œMaybe I can enter into the images to see what we cannot see: what happened inside the prisons, traces of torture,â€ she said. This led to her next film â€œ48,â€ fuelled by a simple idea: mugshots and people talking about the mugshots.

	Although she had the testimonies of the former prisoners typed out, at some point she threw them away, she explained, and worked directly with the recordings and the images, â€œediting the film through listening,â€ she said. What was important, she found, was not just what was said, but the way it was said, complete with pauses. She said that the way she edited the testimonies have been compared to a Japanese haiku.

schema.headline: Documentary Filmmaker Susana de Sousa Dias on Revealing the Terror of Portugalâ€™s Fascist Regime

title: â€˜The Beatlesâ€™ Movies Cast â€˜Game of Thronesâ€™ Star Harry Lloyd as Producer George Martin (EXCLUSIVE)
description:
The Beatles have found their legendary producer. 

	Harry Lloyd, the British actor best known for playing Viserys Targaryen in the first season â€œGam
body:
The Beatles have found their legendary producer. 

	Harry Lloyd, the British actor best known for playing Viserys Targaryen in the first season â€œGame of Thrones,â€ is set to portray George Martin in the upcoming four-partÂ Beatles biopic by director Sam Mendes.

	Lloyd joins Paul Mescal as Paul McCartney, Harrison Dickinson as John Lennon and Barry Keoghan as Ringo Starr and Joseph Quinn as George Harrison in Sony Picturesâ€˜ â€œThe Beatles â€” A Four-Film Cinematic Event,â€ due for release in 2028. 
	

	The casting is being revealed by Martinâ€™s son, Giles Martin, in a pre-recorded interview going out on the Ryan Tubridy Show on Virgin Radio U.K later on Friday. â€œHeâ€™s really good. Heâ€™s very committed,â€ he said. Variety has since confirmed the casting with the production.


	Martin â€” was passed away in 2016 â€”Â was commonly referred to as the â€œfifth Beatleâ€ for his extensive involvement in each of the bandâ€™s original albums. He wrote most of the orchestral and string arrangements and also played piano or keyboards on a number of their tracks. Once described as â€œthe worldâ€™s most famous record producer,â€ across a 60-year career Martin produced 30 number one hit singles in U.K. and 23 in the U.S., winning six Grammys. 

	Alongside â€œGame of Thrones,â€ Lloyd has appeared in major shows such as â€œWolf Hallâ€ and â€œLegion,â€ playing Charles Xavier. He is due to star in the upcoming sixth season of â€œSlow Horses.â€

	The much-discussed Beatles films are now in production and being directed back-to-back by Mendes, with a trio of award-winning writers â€” Jez Butterworth, Peter Straughan and Jack Thorne â€” having penned the scripts. Production is expected to carry on into late 2026, with Sony releasing all four movies simultaneously in April 2028.

schema.headline: â€˜The Beatlesâ€™ Movies Cast â€˜Game of Thronesâ€™ Star Harry Lloyd as Producer George Martin (EXCLUSIVE)

title: â€˜DJ Tilluâ€™ Director Vimal Krishna Wraps Kashmir Shoot for India-Indonesia Co-Production â€˜Anumana Pakshiâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Vimal Krishna, who wrote and directed Telugu-language blockbuster â€œDJ Tillu,â€ has wrapped a key shooting schedule in Kashmir for his next film â€œAnum
body:
Vimal Krishna, who wrote and directed Telugu-language blockbuster â€œDJ Tillu,â€ has wrapped a key shooting schedule in Kashmir for his next film â€œAnumana Pakshi,â€ marking an India-Indonesia co-production venture.

	The character-driven feature stars Rag Mayur, known for â€œSivarapalli,â€ in the lead role alongside Merin Philip. The project is being produced through a partnership between Chilaka Productions and Spectrum Films, with producers Rajiv Chilaka, Rajesh Jagtiani and Hirachand Dand, and co-producer Bharath Laxmipati.
	

	Chilaka is the creator of iconic animation character â€œChhota Bheem,â€ and the founder and CEO of Green Gold Animation.


	The production recently completed a 20-day schedule in Pahalgam and Srinagar in Kashmir, following all necessary security protocols under CRPF (Central Reserve Police Force) guidance. According to the producers, this marks the first film to shoot in Kashmir, particularly Pahalgam, following a tragedy that occurred in the region earlier this year.

	The Kashmir schedule represents approximately 80% of the filmâ€™s completion, with the next shooting phase planned for late November. The team previously filmed a brief schedule in Visakhapatnam in September.

	The ensemble cast includes Prince Cecil, Ananya, Charith, Brahmaji, Ajay and veteran actress Raasi in supporting roles. Sri Charan Pakala is composing the music, while Sunil Kumar Nama serves as cinematographer.

	Chilaka is participating in the ongoing WAVES Film Bazaar, the market arm of the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa.

schema.headline: â€˜DJ Tilluâ€™ Director Vimal Krishna Wraps Kashmir Shoot for India-Indonesia Co-Production â€˜Anumana Pakshiâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Steven Soderbergh Says His John Lennon Doc Will Get People to Hear â€˜What John and Yoko Had To Say on That Afternoon Before He Was Killedâ€™
description: Stephen Soderbergh has completed his still-untitled documentary centered on John Lennonâ€˜s final interview which he describes as â€œan incredible histo
body:
Stephen Soderbergh has completed his still-untitled documentary centered on John Lennonâ€˜s final interview which he describes as â€œan incredible historical documentâ€ that is â€œeven more relevant todayâ€ than it was 45 years ago on the fateful day of December 8, 1980, when Lennon was killed.

	â€œIâ€™m excited about it,â€ Soderbergh said, speaking at the inaugural Doha Film Festival where his latest film â€œThe Christophersâ€ is launching internationally after premiering in Toronto.
	

	Given the interviewâ€™s historical importance, the job is to present the doc â€œin such a way that it enhances the interview and doesnâ€™t distract from it,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m not looking to re-invent the form. Iâ€™m just hoping to create a film that gets as many people as possible to hear what John and Yoko had to say on that afternoon before he was killed,â€ Soderbergh noted.


	â€œThey were both so free in their discussions. As someone who has been interviewed many times I was surprised at how open and excited they were to talk,â€ he continued. â€œYou would think they had never been interviewed before.â€ 

	â€œSo I want that to come across to the audience. Everything that they said 45 years ago is not just relevant today. Itâ€™s even more relevant in terms or relationships, politics, how we treat each other. How systems work on the individual and above all on the importance of love in our daily life and our world,â€ the prolific director went on to add. 

	Lennonâ€™s final in-depth interview took place alongside Yoko on Dec. 8, 1980.Â He had just turned 40 and emerged from a five-year hiatus from the music industry to care for his son, Sean. It was the only radio interview granted around the release of their album,Â â€œDouble Fantasy.â€ That afternoon, they met a team from RKO Radio at the Dakota, their New York City apartment building and held a wide-ranging conversation.
	

	Twelve hours later Lennon was dead â€” gunned down outside the Dakota by Mark David Chapman. 

	The still untitled John Lennon doc marks Soderberghâ€™s first feature documentary in many years, followingÂ â€œAnd Everything Is Going Fine,â€ a portrait of artist Spalding Gray released in 2010.

	Executive producers on the project include Soderbergh, Michael Sugar and David Hillman of Sugar23, and Nancy Saslow and David Hudson of Mishpookah Entertainment Group.

schema.headline: Steven Soderbergh Says His John Lennon Doc Will Get People to Hear â€˜What John and Yoko Had To Say on That Afternoon Before He Was Killedâ€™

title: Â Tallinn Black Nights Grand Prix Winner Sengedorj Janchivdorj Returns in Competition With â€˜The Muralistâ€™
description: TALLINN, Estonia â€” Mongolian filmmaker Sengedorj Janchivdorj is back in competition at the Tallinn Black Nights Film Festival with â€œThe Muralist,â€ o
body:
TALLINN, Estonia â€” Mongolian filmmaker Sengedorj Janchivdorj is back in competition at the Tallinn Black Nights Film Festival with â€œThe Muralist,â€ one of 16 world premieres in the main section.

	One of Mongoliaâ€™s most acclaimed and prolific filmmakers, Sengedorj won the festivalâ€™s Grand Prix in 2024 for â€œSilent City Driver,â€ which has gone on to represent Mongolia in the international feature film category at 2026â€™s 98th Academy Awards.
	

	A visually striking meditation on art, memory, and reconciliation, â€œThe Muralistâ€ is the film Sengedorj says he always wanted to make: â€œIâ€™ve been making movies for over 20 years. One of my secret and biggest dreams was to make a movie about an artist. In my other movies, there was always an artist in the background. This time, the muralist is the main character,â€ he told Variety.


	The film follows Bayaraa, a once-successful muralist who returns to Mongolia after years living in Europe with little else than a box of paints, a rooftop tent and his loyal stray dog. Day after day, he works to transform an abandoned factory wall into a sweeping mural of mythical Mongolian landscapes, which contrast with the surrounding green hills and creeping urbanization. As demolition looms and a group of Japanese tourists take an interest in his art, Bayaraa is forced to face the ghosts of the family he left behind, under the watchful presence of a balloon tethered to him.

	Shot by longtime collaborator Nergui Erdenekhuyag, â€œThe Muralistâ€ features Sengedorjâ€™s trademark poetic imagery. It is a loose adaptation of â€œPicture of the Soul,â€ a romantic novel by Mongolian author Khishigjargal Dashdorj, who co-wrote and executive produced the film.
	

	At its core, the film grapples with a dilemma every artist faces, said the director: â€œTo choose between art or life. Bayaraa chose art but [his life] is not balanced and thatâ€™s why he regrets it. But I donâ€™t want to tell the audience what to think, I want to leave it up to them to decide,â€ he says.

	Symbolizing the blurred line between art and everyday reality, the balloon changes color with Bayaraaâ€™s mood as he confronts his past, which unfolds in nostalgic black-and-white flashbacks.Â 

	The score, by Italian-educated Mongolian composer TsolmonbayarÂ Munkhtovch, also reflects this evolution, as uplifting piano solos make way for a gently nostalgic cello-violin-piano trio.

	Sengedorj says he found his lead actor, B.S.Bayinerile, in Inner Mongolia after a long search. â€œThe character of Bayaraa is very introverted, he speaks little. Itâ€™s as if itâ€™s raining inside â€“ every time he meets with his daughter, it rains. That sadness, all of those emotions, had to be reflected in the actorâ€™s eyes and his face.â€

	Japan-based Mongolian actress IshiyamaÂ Gegeenzaya plays Bayaraaâ€™s long-lost daughter.

	Production was brisk but intensive, spanning July and August 2024. The film was shot on location in an abandoned Soviet factory on the outskirts of Ulaanbaatar, with interior scenes filmed in one of Mongoliaâ€™s large Russian-era stages.

	Looking ahead, Sengedorj says he has completed the script for his next film which he describes as an ambitious love story set during an art festival in Italy.Â 

	The directorâ€™s return to Tallinnâ€™s main competition underscores the growing visibility of Mongoliaâ€™s cinema, boosted in recent years by funding from the countryâ€™s new National Film Council. Films like â€œIf Only I Could Hibernateâ€ (Cannes 2023) and â€œCity of Windâ€ (Venice Orizzonti 2023) have brought global attention, while shorts such as â€œSnow in Septemberâ€ have won top prizes at Venice and Toronto.

	Co-produced by Javkhlan Sonomdorj and Lkhamdulam Dashdorj, with Khishigjargal Dashdorj as executive producer, â€œThe Muralistâ€ premiered on Nov. 19 at Tallinn Black Nights Film Festival. The main competition winner will be announced Nov. 21, with the festival wrapping on Nov. 23.

schema.headline: Â Tallinn Black Nights Grand Prix Winner Sengedorj Janchivdorj Returns in Competition With â€˜The Muralistâ€™

title: Indian Pop Star King, Warner Music Unveil High-Energy Video for â€˜Kamaal Hai,â€™ First Taste of Sixth Studio Album (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Indian pop star King has unveiled the video for â€œKamaal Hai,â€ a pop-dance collaboration with Warner Music India that serves as the lead single from
body:
Indian pop star King has unveiled the video for â€œKamaal Hai,â€ a pop-dance collaboration with Warner Music India that serves as the lead single from his sixth studio album, set for release early next year.

	The track, composed by King and Aditya Dev with lyrics by King, features actor Sahher Bambba, who recently appeared in â€œThe Ba***ds of Bollywood.â€ 

	Director Lendrick Kumar helmed the music video, which was shot in Kochi. The cinematic visual blends action and comedy elements, starring King and Bambba alongside veteran actor Lilliput (M.M. Faruqui) in a stylized gangster setting featuring vintage automobiles and period aesthetics.
	

	â€œâ€˜Kamaal Haiâ€™ marks the beginning of a new era for me, and I wanted the visuals to feel just as explosive as the song,â€ King said. â€œWorking with Sahher Bambba and Lilliput sir was an absolute joy. They brought so much charm, timing, and personality to the world we were building. Most importantly, collaborating with Lendrick Kumar on the video was an incredible experience as his vision, pace, and treatment turned the track into this larger-than-life ride filled with dance, action, and humor.â€


	Bambba added: â€œWorking on this song has been such a refreshing experience for me. The team, especially Lendrick, created a playful, supportive space that really allowed the performance to breathe. And with Kingâ€™s easy, infectious energy on set, everything flowed even better. Iâ€™m truly thrilled with what weâ€™ve created together.â€

	King, known for hits including â€œMaan Meri Jaanâ€ and â€œTu Jaana Na Piya,â€ became one of the first Indian artist to break into Spotifyâ€™s Global Top 25. He is scheduled to perform at the Music Head Festival in Itanagar on Nov. 22, with additional Indian dates to follow.
	

	Watch the video here:

schema.headline: Indian Pop Star King, Warner Music Unveil High-Energy Video for â€˜Kamaal Hai,â€™ First Taste of Sixth Studio Album (EXCLUSIVE)

title: â€˜Sisu: Road to Revengeâ€™ Review: After Nixing Countless Nazis, One-Man Army Goes Up Against the Russians in Gleefully Excessive Sequel
description: A sleeper hit in 2022, Jalmari Helanderâ€™s â€œSisuâ€ was a cartoonishly down-and-dirty adrenaline rush for action fans, not unlike the OG â€œMad Maxâ€ deca
body:
A sleeper hit in 2022, Jalmari Helanderâ€™s â€œSisuâ€ was a cartoonishly down-and-dirty adrenaline rush for action fans, not unlike the OG â€œMad Maxâ€ decades earlier. That particular comparison grows even more apt with the arrival of â€œSisu: Road to Revenge,â€ in which Jorma Tommilaâ€™s seemingly unkillable protagonist must battle innumerable bad guys at high speed on various forms of transport.Â 

	Bigger isnâ€™t necessarily better, and this larger-scaled sequel almost inevitably lacks some of the freshness that made the original such a kick. Still, the directorâ€™s undeniable flair for gleefully excessive mayhem and propulsive pacing will more than satisfy those who loved its predecessor. Its comparatively lean, mean progress feels particularly welcome after so many recent screen thrill rides that delivered far less punch at much greater length and expense.Â 
	

	Last time around, decommissioned Finnish army commando Aatami Korpi (Tommila) only wanted to be left alone as WW2 wound down. Alas, finding gold in the Lapland tundra awakened the greed of departing Nazi forces with zero idea who they were messing with: a â€œone-man death squadâ€ whoâ€™d already claimed many a uniformed Russian life after Soviet forces killed his family during the brief but brutal â€œWinter Warâ€ of 1940. His vengeance was sweet, gory and spectacularly over-the-top.Â 


	This time, the terrifically fit 60-something protagonist is encountered in 1946, the global conflict now officially well over. Heâ€™s driving a huge truck to his old home, which thanks to redrawn borders now lies in Russian territory. He intends to dismantle, then reassemble it in what remains of Finland. But Soviet authorities havenâ€™t forgotten that this â€œlegendâ€ singlehandedly snuffed out more than 300 of their troops. 
	

	Red Army officer Igor Draganov (Stephen Lang) is released from a Siberian prison â€” where heâ€™s being held for committing innumerable needless wartime atrocities â€” by a KBG bigwig (Richard Brake) to ensure Aatami never sees Finnish soil again. The two adversaries are uniquely matched, in that Korpi knows the other brutally murdered his wife and sons, while Draganov wonâ€™t feel heâ€™s truly completed the job until the father is dead, too.

	This setup takes about 10 minutes, after which itâ€™s one dynamic set-piece after another: Aatami manages to escape an initial roadblock-cum-ambush, then attack by phalanx of motorcylists, followed by fighter planes with machine guns. After a brief aquatic interlude, thereâ€™s a protracted climax aboard a train speeding back to Siberia, bearing myriad armed Soviets plus one bloodied, shackled prisoner. Needless to say, the survival odds are stacked â€” against the poor Russkies, that is.Â 

	Divided into six titled â€œchapters,â€ these episodes are mostly aces in terms of staging, stuntwork and CGI. Occasionally, the violence comes so thick, weâ€™re not quite sure what just happened. And even within the suspended-disbelief bounds established, a few hairbreadth escapes are preposterous, notably one where Aatami makes a tank do mid-air acrobatics to leap past a barrier.Â 

	Entertaining as it is, such craziness isnâ€™t so well supported by a thread of black comedy as it was in the first â€œSisu.â€ You could also argue thereâ€™s a bit too much dwelling on general ickiness here, as the manliest man in the far north seems to be frequently digging bullets and other objects out of his lacerated flesh. (Spending pretty much the last half hour bleeding in boxer shorts amid subzero weather appears not to bother him in the slightest.)Â 

	But Tommilaâ€™s turn retains a degree of flinty humor, even some warmth â€” despite never getting so much as a word to speak. Langâ€™s expletive-riddled speech comprises most of the dialogue. If Draganov isnâ€™t the most distinctive villain role heâ€™s ever essayed, he still fills its shoes well, receiving a particularly explosive exit as reward. Brakeâ€™s part is brief, while other cast members provide no more than cannon fodder. The canine performer playing the protagonistâ€™s Bedlington terrier disappears for quite some time, in one among several minor if conspicuous plot holes in Helanderâ€™s script that itâ€™s best just to step over.Â 
	

	Shot largely in Estonia, â€œSisu: Road to Revengeâ€ is muscular rather than ingratiating in most aspects, from Mika Orasmaâ€™s widescreen cinematography to the physical design contributions. The fairly standard action bombast of Juri Seppa and Tuomas Wainolaâ€™s original score gets some idiosyncratic flavor via passages of throat singing and spaghetti-Western-style whistling. The English-language version reviewed has a bit of subtitled Finnish speech toward the end; a separate Finnish-language edition is also in release.

schema.headline: â€˜Sisu: Road to Revengeâ€™ Review: After Nixing Countless Nazis, One-Man Army Goes Up Against the Russians in Gleefully Excessive Sequel

title: â€˜Chhota Bheemâ€™ Producer, â€˜Ultramarinesâ€™ Director Team on India-U.K. Co-Production â€˜The Assassinâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)
description: Indian animation powerhouse Green Gold Animation, the studio behind popular childrenâ€™s franchise â€œChhota Bheem,â€ and U.K.-based Red Kite Animation h
body:
Indian animation powerhouse Green Gold Animation, the studio behind popular childrenâ€™s franchise â€œChhota Bheem,â€ and U.K.-based Red Kite Animation have partnered on â€œThe Assassin,â€ an adult-oriented animated feature that marks a significant India-U.K. co-production venture.

	The project was unveiled at the WAVES Film Bazaar, the market component of the International Film Festival of India, Goa, by Rajiv Chilaka, founder and CEO of Green Gold Animation, and Ken Anderson, founder and CEO of Red Kite Animation.
	

	â€œThe Assassinâ€ is written and directed by Martyn Pick, whose previous directing credit includes the CGI action-animation feature â€œUltramarines: A Warhammer 40,000 Movieâ€ (2010). Martha MacDiarmid, known for her work on â€œNessie Junior,â€ serves as script editor, continuing her creative collaboration with Red Kite.


	The film is set in a fractured near-future metropolis and follows an ordinary young man pushed to breaking point after a devastating industrial tragedy. As corporate power tightens its grip on the city, his search for justice drives him into a dangerous transformation, igniting events that challenge the system from within.

	â€œâ€˜The Assassinâ€™ is an ultra cinematic action film that uses bold 21c century visuals to give the audience a visceral experience of the heroâ€™s physical and psychological journey. For me it is the culmination of a career fusing animation and live action for maximum expressive power. within the dynamic power of genre and commercial storytelling. Red Kite have superb insight, both commercial and creative, about animation and film both as storytelling and as a visual medium. Green Gold combine outstanding artistic skill and understanding with a powerful pipeline. They are the perfect partners to realise the Assassinâ€™s extraordinary vision,â€ Pick said.
	

	Visual development is being led by Pick in collaboration with Green Goldâ€™s Hyderabad-based design team, whose concept art and mood exploration establish the stylistic foundation for the ambitious animated feature.

	The partnership represents a creative departure for Green Gold Animation, which has built its reputation primarily on family-friendly content, most notably the â€œChhota Bheemâ€ franchise. The collaboration signals the studioâ€™s expansion into adult-oriented animation and global co-production partnerships.

	The film aims to qualify under the India-U.K. Co-Production Treaty, with production planned across Hyderabad and the U.K. The financing strategy includes the U.K.â€™s Independent Film Tax Credit, with both studios participating as equitable partners throughout development, production and distribution.

	â€œThis partnership represents a powerful alignment of ambition and creative energy,â€ Anderson said. â€œâ€˜The Assassinâ€™ pushes into bold new territory for adult animation, and collaborating with Rajiv and the outstanding artists at Green Gold gives the film an expansive visual identity from the very beginning.â€

	Chilaka added: â€œGreen Gold has always championed original ideas and distinctive visual storytelling. Working with Red Kite on this India-U.K. feature strengthens our commitment to global collaboration and to creating boundary-pushing animated cinema.â€

	The project combines guerrilla live-action, rotoscoping and high-end animation techniques. The film is currently in active development, with financing and production planning underway.

schema.headline: â€˜Chhota Bheemâ€™ Producer, â€˜Ultramarinesâ€™ Director Team on India-U.K. Co-Production â€˜The Assassinâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Neon and Nascent Doha Film Committee Sign Four-Year Co-Production Deal
description: Qatarâ€™s nascent Film Committee and Oscar-winning U.S. indie powerhouse Neon have signed a four-year co-development, co-production and co financing d
body:
Qatarâ€™s nascent Film Committee and Oscar-winning U.S. indie powerhouse Neon have signed a four-year co-development, co-production and co financing deal. 

	Itâ€™s one of several milestone agreements unveiled at the inaugural Doha Film Festivalâ€˜s Industry Days, by Hassan Al Thawadi, the Qatari lawyer who chairs the Qatar Film Committee and oversaw the 2022 FIFA World Cup soccer tournament.


	The Qatar Film Committee, an official body that is part of the Media City Qatar hub that is tasked with driving growth of the countryâ€™s entertainment industry, also announced the launch of a regional rebate, details of which will soon be specified and, also still unspecified collaborations with the Cannes and Cairo film festivals. 
	

	â€œWe are building the foundations of a world class [film and TV] ecosystem with new infrastructure, productionÂ facilities and post production capabilities supported by vast technology, and data analytics, said Al Thawadi (pictured) at the Industry Days event which included a fireside chat with Neon CEO and founder Tom Quinn. â€œOur mission is to create an environment where filmmakers can dream openly,â€ he added.Â 


	The agreement between Neon and the committee sees the partners co-developing and producing six to 10 feature films and short films over a four-year period.

	â€œOur collaboration with Neon represents an important milestone in the Film Committeeâ€™s mission to support Arab cinema,â€ said Al Thawadi in a statement.

	â€œThis agreement is about more than financing films, itâ€™s about creating a new platform for Arabic andregional storytelling, ensuring that stories from Qatar and the wider Arab world are seen, celebrated,and shared globally,â€ he added. â€œThrough this partnership, we are deepening creative collaboration between the Arab world and global cinema, helping position the region as a key player in the creative economy of the Global South.â€
	

	Commented Quinn: â€œNeon has always been committed to supporting international cinema, and our partnership with the Film Committee at Media City Qatar gives us the opportunity to elevate an even richer diversity of filmmaking for audiences around the world.â€

	Al Thawadi also announced a partnership between Doha-based Katara Studios and U.S. indie studio Department M, founded by Mike Larocca and Michael Schaefer, that will see them partner on a biopic about the Syrian military officer known as Caesar who put his own life at risk by smuggling tens of thousands of pictures depicting torture under Bashar Assad to expose the Syrian regimeâ€™s torture and human-rights abuses.

	As for the rebate, which is called the Qatar Screen Production Incentive, it offers and up to 50% in cash incentive on qualifying Qatari production expenditure, combining a 40% base rebate with an additional uplift of up to 10% for productions that meet defined criteria such as hiring Qatari talent, investing in local training, promoting Qatari culture, and other aspects of industry development.

	The Industry Days gathered a flurry of major entertainment figures, including A24 cofounder and CEO Daniel Katz, producer Rodrigo Teixeira (â€œIâ€™m Still Hereâ€) and AGC Studios CEOÂ Stuart Ford.

schema.headline: Neon and Nascent Doha Film Committee Sign Four-Year Co-Production Deal

title: Dan LÃ¶wenstein Boards Night Train Media U.K. Microdrama as Tallinn Talks Vertical Storytelling Boom (EXCLUSIVE)
description: British director Dan LÃ¶wenstein, known for vertical dramas like ReelShortâ€™s â€œPride & Prejudice,â€ is set to direct and produce a new and as-yet untit
body:
British director Dan LÃ¶wenstein, known for vertical dramas like ReelShortâ€™s â€œPride & Prejudice,â€ is set to direct and produce a new and as-yet untitled U.K.-made microdrama currently in development with Night Train Media and Spirit Studios.

	The project was confirmed by Eccho Rights and Night Train executive Sarah Postlethwaite during a panel at the Tallinn Black Nights Festival reflecting the formatâ€™s rapid global rise and Britainâ€™s potentially growing role as a production base for mobile-native storytelling. Postlethwaite described it as â€œone of the first U.K.-produced vertical dramas.â€
	

	LÃ¶wenstein, who has directed some 18 vertical mini series in the past year for companies including the Chinese-backed U.S. platform ReelShort, has already put together a series overview and a first 10-episodes breakdown with two co-writers: a TikTok content creator â€œwith 4.2 million views,â€ and a â€œmore traditional scripted content comedian.â€


	â€œWeâ€™re getting to a point where we can start going out to platforms and commissioners and try and find whoâ€™s going to have our show. Weâ€™re at very, very early stages,â€ said Postlethwaite. â€œThey all have different models: some will commission, others will licence. Weâ€™re trying to learn as much as we can and work out whatâ€™s right. But, yes, itâ€™s fresh to us all,â€ she told the industry crowd at the Nordic Hotel Forum.

	The news came during a broader discussion on vertical storytelling entitled Vertical Horizons â€“ Does Size Matter? Rewiring Serialized Content to Fit Gen Zâ€™s Consuming Habits, an Industry@Tallinn & Baltic Event session exploring how short-form vertical dramas, known for fast-paced shoots and low-budget execution, are reshaping story structure, production and monetization models.
	

	Moderated by Marike Muselaers from Nordisk Film Production, the panel brought together Postlethwaite; Seriencamp co-founder Gerhard Maier; U.S. writer-producer Andrew Higton and director Shaun Higton; and Czech producer Krystof Safer, the founder of vertical film festival Vertifilms.

	Maier opened with a rapid history of the format, tracing its roots from early Snapchat experiments and home-screen narratives to the fast-cut, emotion-led edits inspired by Chinese and South Korean creators that now define it.

	The Higton brothers, who created Snapchatâ€™s teen horror series â€œDead of Night,â€ reflected on their first experience working in the format more than five years ago.

	Asked how he developed a visual approach for mobile-native viewers, Shaun Higton explained that he simply watched teenagers scrolling on public transport, thumbs hovering, ready to swipe away at any second. That observation shaped their entire approach: he and his brother decided to strip down their original script.

	â€œYou canâ€™t have a super complicated narrative, itâ€™s got to be easily understood and pitched.â€Â 

	The brothers added that Snapchat fully financed the series and provided analytics to keep audiences engaged, right down to user habits. â€œAnything from emojis to not using capital letters â€“ â€˜Thatâ€™s not what kids do!â€™â€

	The panel also examined the economics driving Asiaâ€™s booming microdrama market. Episodes typically run two-to-three minutes across at least 60 installments, with viewers paying per episode after the first free batch. Payment is made via coins, tokens earned through games or ads or subscriptions â€“ a model can generate â€œup to a million dollars per day in revenue,â€ Muselaers noted, prompting Safer to stress that Europe needs to pay attention to Asiaâ€™s lead.

	â€œI think we are underestimating China,â€ Safer said, noting that the appeal lies in stories that â€œgo to the point. Itâ€™s not just trash: itâ€™s about love, honesty, truthfulness. They have all the messages that we are trying to deliver in our films, theyâ€™re just doing it in a different form.â€

	Total production costs can be as low as $100,000, and timelines are equally aggressive. â€œFrom the moment you see the script â€˜til it appears on the screen, there are about three to four weeksâ€¦ 60, 70, 80 minutes of content, shot within five, six or seven days â€“ thatâ€™s 14 minutes a day!â€ Safer said.Â 
	

	Looking ahead, Maier argued that vertical and horizontal storytelling are increasingly influencing each other rather than siloed. Speaking to Variety after the session, he teased one of the German projects debuting at Seriencamp next June. Titled â€œThree Minutes,â€ the show lets users sign up to an app that randomly gives them a three-minute window to broadcast to millions, forcing them â€œto think on [their] feet and do something crazy,â€ he explained. â€œThe vertical is a hook into the horizontal series that will follow the story of the protagonists. Itâ€™s a super crazy, great idea!â€

	The Industry@Tallinn & Baltic Event runs until Nov. 21. The Tallinn Black Nights Film Festival wraps on Sunday.Â

title: Sia Plans to Testify at Upcoming Spousal Support and Custody Hearing
description:
Sia
                          I'll Be 'Unstoppable' at Hearing ...
                          Says
body:
Sia
                          I'll Be 'Unstoppable' at Hearing ...
                          Says She Plans to Testify
                      
                  
                        Published November 20, 2025 1:57 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Sia's laid out the witnesses she plans to call at her upcoming spousal support and custody hearing ... and she's listed herself as chief among them.
      
    
          According to a new filing, Sia says she expects to take the stand at a hearing for approximately 2 hours on issues such as spousal support, custody, visitation, attorney's fees, and more.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Sia also lists her estranged husband, Daniel Bernad, who she expects her lawyers to cross-examine on various issues like custody ... and accountant Tracy Katz, who she says will testify about child support and other financial issues.
      

          As you know ... Sia -- who is being repped by disso queen Laura Wasser -- and Daniel are going through a very messy divorce and custody battle over their son, Somersault.
      
    
          Daniel claimed Sia's debilitating drug problem posed a problem with parenting effectively ... while Sia fired back by claiming Daniel had been investigated for child pornography.
      
    
          A judge previously ruled most of the facts in Daniel's filing were old news and shot down his emergency request for full custody of their son ... and subsequently ordered them to go to mediation and try to hammer out a custody agreement. Â And if that doesn't work, it looks like they'll hash things out in front of the judge.
      
    
          The hearing is set for January 14, 2026.

title: CeeDee Lamb Reveals Why He And George Pickens Were Benched Monday Vs. Raiders
description:
CeeDee Lamb, George Pickens
                          Missed Curfew Sunday Night
body:
CeeDee Lamb, George Pickens
                          Missed Curfew Sunday Night
                          ... Led To MNF Benching
                      
                  
                        Published November 20, 2025 3:21 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The mystery surrounding the benching of CeeDee Lamb and George Pickens Monday night in Las Vegas has finally been solved ... as Lamb says the star wideouts missed team curfew after having dinner at a nearby resort.
      
    
          The Cowboys' All-Pro wide receiver made the revelation while speaking with reporters in Dallas, saying the guys grabbed some grub and a few drinks at Red Rock Casino, about 20 minutes from where the team was staying for the Raiders game.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The explanation comes after rumors were circulating online indicating Lamb was spotted not just hanging out at the Casino on game day at 7:30 AM, but also throwing up.
      

          CeeDee denied those reports and took offense at the suggestion.
      
    
          "I know how to hold my liquor," Lamb said.
      
    
          The explanation comes after all parties involved opted not to explain why the two were benched in the first series of their win against the Raiders, including Cowboys head coach Brian Schottenheimer, who called it a "coach's decision" during his postgame media scrum.
      
    
          "There were some things that were missed," he said on Monday.
      
    
      
      â€” Brandon Loree (@Brandoniswrite) November 18, 2025
              @Brandoniswrite
          
  
    
          Whatever happened didn't seem to cause much animosity between coach and player ... as cameras caught Schottenheimer, in his first year at the helm in Big D, celebrating with his benched players after a Cowboys touchdown drive.
      
    
          It happens to the best of us, CeeDee. Next time ... multiple alarms!

title: Meghan King Lost Custody After Allegedly Giving Twin Unprescribed Medication
description:
Meghan King
                          Allegedly Lost Custody Of Kids After Giving Twin Unprescrib
body:
Meghan King
                          Allegedly Lost Custody Of Kids After Giving Twin Unprescribed Meds
                      
                  
                        Published November 20, 2025 5:37 PM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Meghan King temporarily lost custody of her three children to ex-husband Jim Edmonds after allegedly giving one of her twin sons unprescribed medication and allegedly asking his school nurse to administer it ... TMZ has confirmed.
      
    
          We're told "The Real Housewives of Orange County" star allegedly gave Hayes, one of the 6-year-old twins, Ritalin multiple times, despite the child not having an ADHD diagnosis.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          According to sources, the situation escalated when King allegedly asked the school nurse to give Hayes the medication as well. That request reportedly triggered a Child Protective Services investigation.
      

          King was granted supervised visitation twice a week with Hayes, his twin brother Hart, and their older sister, Aspen.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          As we previously reported ... a temporary restraining order was put in place after a school employee allegedly contacted CPS with concerns. A judge is expected to consider a more permanent solution in a custody hearing set for early December.
      
    
          King and Edmonds, who tied the knot in 2014 before splitting in 2019 amid a cheating scandal, have been operating under a joint custody agreement since May 2021.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          We've reached out to reps for Meghan ... so far, no word back yet. A rep for Jim had no comment.
      
    
          Page Six was the first to report.
